title: Quiz 2: The Basics of EP Studies
topicName: Cardiology Cardiac Electrophysiology  A Visual Guide for Nurses
description: Assessment on catheter placement, signal processing, basic conduction intervals, and the standard SVT diagnostic study protocol.

questions.question: Identify the Coronary Sinus (CS) catheter in the standard fluoroscopic view.

options.text: The catheter curving around the AV groove (Green arrow equivalent)
The catheter in the High Right Atrium (Red arrow equivalent)
The catheter at the Right Ventricular Apex (Magenta arrow equivalent)
The catheter across the Tricuspid Valve (Yellow arrow equivalent)

questions.explanation: The CS catheter curves around the AV groove, appearing to wrap around the heart in the LAO projection. It records left atrial and left ventricular signals.
questions.hint: Look for the catheter that appears to wrap around the back of the heart.

questions.question: Arrange the standard signal sequence seen during Sinus Rhythm from earliest to latest.
questions.explanation: Activation travels from SA node (HRA) -> AV Node (HIS A) -> Left Atrium (CS A) -> His Bundle (H) -> Bundle Branches/Purkinje -> RV Apex (RVA V) -> Base of Ventricles (HIS V).
questions.hint: Follow the electrical impulse from the sinus node down to the ventricles.

questions.question: The ___BLANK___ interval represents the transnodal conduction time and normally ranges between 70 and ___BLANK___ milliseconds.
questions.explanation: The A-H interval (Atrial to His) represents conduction time through the AV node. The normal range is typically 70-120 ms.
questions.hint: This interval is measured on the HIS channel.

questions.question: What is the primary function of setting a 'High Pass' filter to 30 Hz on intracardiac channels?

options.text: To remove low-frequency signals like respiration and baseline wander
To amplify the size of the electrogram
To filter out 60 Hz AC interference

questions.explanation: A High Pass filter allows frequencies HIGHER than the setting (e.g., >30 Hz) to pass, effectively filtering out LOW frequency components (<30 Hz) like respiration and baseline drift.
questions.hint: Think about what kind of signals are 'passed' through.

questions.question: During incremental ventricular pacing, you observe that the V-A time remains constant despite increasing the pacing rate. What does this suggest?

options.text: Retrograde conduction via an Accessory Pathway
Retrograde conduction via the AV Node

questions.explanation: The AV node has decremental properties (V-A time lengthens as rate increases). Accessory pathways typically conduct in an 'all-or-none' fashion without decrement; conduction time remains fixed.
questions.hint: Does the AV node normally conduct faster or slower when stressed?

questions.question: What clinical term is used to describe a sudden increase in the A-H interval (>50 ms) during atrial extra-stimulus testing?
questions.explanation: A 'jump' is the hallmark of dual AV nodal physiology, representing a shift from fast pathway conduction (which blocks) to slow pathway conduction (which conducts with delay).
questions.hint: It implies a sudden change in conduction time.

questions.question: Match the pacing maneuver to the refractory period it determines.
questions.explanation: Extra-stimulus testing (coupling intervals) determines Effective Refractory Periods (ERP). Incremental pacing (continuous drive) determines functional limits like Wenckebach.
questions.hint: Consider the direction of conduction and the result of the block.

questions.question: A 'Chevron' pattern on the Coronary Sinus catheter (CS 1-2 and CS 9-10 activating simultaneously) typically indicates the catheter is too deep.
questions.explanation: True. A chevron pattern often results from the catheter being advanced too far into the CS, where it detects Bachmann's bundle activation early on both proximal and distal poles.
questions.hint: Visualize the shape of a chevron ^.

questions.question: Which of the following indicate 'Eccentric' atrial activation during ventricular pacing? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Earliest atrial signal is at the distal CS (1-2)
Earliest atrial signal is at the HIS catheter
Earliest atrial signal is at the Lateral Right Atrium
The atrial activation sequence mirrors normal sinus rhythm

questions.explanation: Concentric activation is earliest at the AV node (HIS). Eccentric means 'off-center', implying the earliest signal is elsewhere (like distal CS for a left lateral AP, or lateral RA for a right free wall AP).
questions.hint: Eccentric means away from the center (septum/AV node).
